Meaning: RISE - Research and Information State Education Trust - is a research charity. It aims to commission research and provide information on state education. RISE reports have covered many issues of particular interest to parents e.g. class size, school reports, home-school agreements, parental involvement in Ofsted inspections, school complaints procedures and school admissions. Research has been funded by various trusts, including the Nuffield Foundation and the Esmee Fairbairn Foundation. The most recent project researched the role of Parent Governor Representatives. Since 2003 all RISE research projects have been published via the Internet.  As well as seeking support for further research projects RISE is working on its information centre, an online catalogue of official on-line education data. This is intended to prove a valuable resource to researchers, information officers and journalists as well as parents, teachers and governors. RISE reports have covered many issues of particular interest to parents e.g. class size, school reports, home-school agreements, parental involvement in Ofsted inspections, school complaints procedures, school admissions and the role of parent governor representatives.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-12

Meaning: Realistic Mathematics Education (RME) is an approach to teaching utilised in the Netherlands and developed over a period of thirty years. The approach is significantly different to the approaches used in England in a number of regards: Use of realistic situations as a means of developing pupils mathematics as opposed to using contexts as an introduction to mathematics or as an application of mathematics. Less emphasis on algorithms and more on sense making and gradual refinement of informal procedures. Emphasis on refining and systematising understanding. Less emphasis on linking single lessons to direct content acquisition and more on gradual development over a longer period of time. Greater emphasis on research into learning and teaching and of trialling and refining materials in schools. Use of guided reinvention rather than discovery learning or teachers explaining. Internationally RME is recognised as a very effective approach to teaching mathematics content (TIMSS 2003) and mathematical problem solving (PISA 2001).Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-12

An RNA vaccine is a novel type of vaccine for providing acquired immunity through an RNA-containing vector. Meaning: The Royal Society for the encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce (RSA) is a multi-disciplinary institution, based in London. The name Royal Society of Arts is frequently used by others for brevity, but the Society itself uses either its full name or the initials RSA. It was founded in 1754 and was granted a Royal Charter in 1847. Notable members have included Benjamin Franklin, Karl Marx, Adam Smith, William Hogarth, Charles Dickens, Guglielmo Marconi and John Diefenbaker. Notwithstanding its establishment credentials, the RSA has always been a radical body which has sought to challenge the status quo and change the world around it "to remove the barriers to social progress". Its founders spoke of the need to "embolden enterprise, enlarge science, refine art, improve our manufactures and extend our commerce", but also of the need to alleviate poverty and secure full employment.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-12

RTI (Real Time Information) was a key government programme which aims to improve the way in 
which employers submit Pay As You Earn (PAYE) information about their employees to HM 
Revenue & Customs (HMRC). The RTI system is designed to deliver benefits to HMRC, employers 
and employees. These benefits include greater stability and reduced risk of over or underpayment 
of tax for employees, simplification for employers at the end of year (no more need for an End of 
Year return) and for dealing with leavers and joiners, and reduced scope for error and fraud. In 
addition, RTI provides the essential platform for Universal Credit, a major government welfare 
reform programme

The School Building Capital programme has increased more than five times since 1996-97. In that financial year the capital budget was 683 million, and this has since increased to over 3.8 billion in 2003-04. There are further increases to 4.5 billion in 2004-05 and 5.1 billion in 2005-06, making a total of 13.4 billion over the three years covered by the most recent spending review. This means that capital investment will be running at a higher level, in real terms, than at any time in the past half century.

Meaning: A SCR should always be undertaken when a child dies (including suicide), and abuse or neglect is known or suspected to be a factor. It should also be carried out when a child dies in custody (in police custody, on remand or following sentencing), in a Youth Offending Institution (YOI), or a Secure Training Centre (STC), or where the child was detained under the Mental Health Act 2005 (para 8.10). The purpose of an SCR is to establish whether there are lessons to be learnt from the case about the way in which local professionals and organisations work together to safeguard and promote the welfare of children.

The Sustainable Development Goals are the blueprint to achieve a better and more sustainable future for all. They address the global challenges we face, including those related to poverty, inequality, climate change, environmental degradation, peace and justice. Single Departmental Plans are revised annually, in line with departments own internal planning, to reflect new priorities or changes in responsibilities. They are linked to the Spending Review and the Budget processes, as part of the planning and performance framework, so that a department can show how it will use its resources (the funding set in its departmental settlement and any adjustments to spending plans made at fiscal events, such as the Budget) to the achieve the outputs and outcomes it will deliver. They include indicators so you can see how the department is performing on each objective during the year. Links are provided to more detailed sources of data and information, such as official statistics and other public data releases. For areas that involve more than one department, the Single Departmental Plans show what each department is responsible for and where there is joint responsibility between departments.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/planning-and-performance-framework/the-governments-planning-and-performance-framework#Single-Departmental-Plans} accessed 2019-08-28
Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-05-31

A scheme that replaces the Graduate Teaching Programme. The aim is to attract up to 4900 high-quality career-changers into the profession. On this programme, schools will receive direct funding to help pay the trainees wage while they are completing their training.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentewsew-school-direct-programme-opens-28-september-2012} accessed 2015-06-10 School Direct (salaried) places These places are aimed mainly at graduates with 3 or more years work experience. However, schools can decide to accept applications from people with less work experience to attract high quality candidates in hard to fill subjects. Prospective candidates are expected to be career changers who can bring valuable skills and experience to the teaching profession. This experience does not have to be from an educational setting. For example, experience could have been gained in the financial, engineering or manufacturing sectors. Trainees are employed as an unqualified teacher. DfE provides funding to lead schools to cover training costs and subsidise the trainee salaries. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/guidance/school-direct-guidance-for-lead-schools} accessed 2019-11-22

Created by combining the Family Support Grant and the Marriage and Relationship Support Grant. 2004. From April 2006 subsumed into the Children, Young People and Families Grant Programme. Further information below from The Knowledge accessed 2019-05-31 The Strengthening Families Grant (SFG) programme (2005- 2008) was designed to help Government drive forward its vision to deliver the Every Child Matters Green Paper outcomes and encourage an environment for mainstreaming Family Support Service. The Marriage and Relationship Support (MARS) and the Family Support Grant (FSG) Programmes combined to form the new Strengthening Families Grant Programme. The aim of the SFG programme was to support and develop activities to enable families to get access to the information, help and advice they want at the time they need it. The SGF focused on national level capacity building and supporting the developments of the Voluntary and Community Sector (VCS) national infrastructure. Funding was for activities that were of national significance, such as innovation, development project work to pilot programmes that were planned to be replicable, and of a specialist provision that was more appropriately delivered at regional or national level.

An association for head teachers of both maintained and independent schools, formed in 1976 from an amalgamation of the Headmasters' Association and the Association of Headmistresses.Source: {Oxford Index|https://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100451195?rskey=fcPouA&result=0&q=Secondary%20Heads%20Association} accessed 2019-05-31 The Secondary Heads Association (SHA) was formed in 1977 by the amalgamation of the AHM and the HMA. In 1983, SHA took a step forward when members overwhelmingly voted to admit deputy heads as full members, thus becoming the first association to recognise the specific role of the senior leadership team. With the growing recognition of and need for shared leadership responsibility, SHA opened membership to assistant heads in 1999 and to bursars and other senior support staff on the leadership team in 2005. By 2005, two-thirds of SHA members were in roles other than that of head. Therefore to better reflect the true makeup of the association, in January 2006, members voted to change the name to the Association of School and College Leaders.Source: {ASCL website|https://www.ascl.org.uk/about-us/history-of-ascl.html} accessed 2019-05-31

A Strategic Housing Land Availability Assessment (SHLAA) is a technical exercise to determine the quantity and suitability of land potentially available for housing development. It is a required part of the evidence base needed for the preparation of a Local Plan (as specified in the National Planning Policy Framework, para. 159). The Mayor carries out a London-wide SHLAA to inform the London Plan as it determines the borough housing targets that form a key part of the Plan.

Definition: Society of Heads of Independent Schools
Meaning: The Society of Heads of Independent Schools (SHMIS) is an Association of Headmasters and Headmistresses of just over 100 well-established Independent schools. It is one of the constituent organisations of the Independent Schools Council. It was previously called the Society of Headmasters and Headmistresses of Independent Schools hence the 'M' in its abbreviated form which is still retained. SHMIS was formed in 1961 when a group of Heads decided they needed a forum in which to share ideas and experience. Since then the Society has grown substantially in size, reputation and effectiveness. SHMIS now represents schools of all sizes throughout the country with a couple of valued overseas members. Many SHMIS schools have a boarding tradition; a number are at the leading edge of education in music, dance and the arts; and several are well-known for their effective support for those with learning difficulties.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-05-31

The Student Loans Company (SLC) is a non-profit making Government-owned organisation set up in 1989 to provide loans and grants to students in universities and colleges in the UK. The company plays a central role in supporting the Higher Education (HE) and Further Education (FE) sectors by: making timely and accurate payments of maintenance grants and loans to learners; and ensuring timely and accurate payments of tuition fee loans to HE and FE providers. We do this by working with the Departments for Education (DfE, England), Education and Lifelong Learning (DELL, Scotland), Education and Skills (DfES, Wales) and the Department for the Economy (DfEcon, Northern Ireland). We also work with the Student Awards Agency for Scotland (SAAS), Higher and Further Education providers and other delivery partners.Source: {SLC website|https://www.slc.co.uk/about-us.aspx} accessed 2019-05-31

Minister for School Standards Nick Gibb said (Tuesday 16 July [2019]): These new qualifications, backed by education experts, will provide recognition for those teachers who want to develop their skills and progress their careers. Our ambition is for teachers to be able to do so without having to pursue traditional leadership routes, instead expanding their expertise in vital areas such as curriculum or behaviour management. The expert panel draws on a range of experience from across the school system, including curriculum experts, current school leaders and leading academics. The group will play an essential role in helping to ensure all the qualifications are aligned in order to maximise the benefits for teachers. The professional qualifications will build on the landmark Early Career Framework, which is set to be backed by at least 130 million a year when fully rolled out. The framework is a two-year package of training and support at the start of a teachers career will include a reduced timetable to allow teachers to make the most of their training.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentewsew-qualifications-to-help-teachers-progress-their-careers} accessed 2019-10-22

The Schools Recruitment Service (SRS) has been established to provide a faster, more efficient and standardised application system to recruit all permanent teaching and support staff in England. It was launched on 20 October 2009, although candidates were able to register from the summer. The contract for delivering SRS has been awarded to Tribal. It aims to save up to 30 million annually if all schools in England sign up with huge savings in time; administration; and the cost of re-advertising posts in national and local media because recruits are better matched to jobs. At launch, 52 local authorities, representing over 8,000 schools, and 32 academies have already signed up to the service.Source: {Schools Recruitment Service|https://www.schoolsrecruitment.education.gov.uk/} accessed 2021-03-01

The Staying Safe Action Plan was published by the Department for Children, Schools and Families in February 2008 in response to the Staying Safe consultation on the first ever cross-Government strategy for improving children and young people's safety.  Staying Safe was launched for consultation in July 2007, and during the consultation period, the Department spoke to parents, children and young people, members of the general public and practitioners about their concerns in relation to children's safety. The Action Plan set out the work which Government took forward over the next three years to drive improvements in children and young people's safety, which will be measured by the new PSA to improve children and young people's safety.  The Staying Safe Action Plan covers three main areas: 1.Universal safeguarding, involving work to keep all children and young people safe and to create safe environments for them 2.Targeted safeguarding to reduce the risks of harm for vulnerable groups of children and young people 3.Responsive safeguarding, involving responding effectively when children are harmed  The Action Plan set out new commitments on children's safety, including a new Â£18m home safety equipment scheme targeted at vulnerable areas, a Child Safety Education Coalition and a new National Safeguarding Unit for the Third Sector. Publication of new guidance The Government announced the publication of new guidance on the safeguarding of disabled children on 9 July 2009. The guidance, produced by the Children's Society on behalf of the Government, advises local organisations on how to best safeguard and promote the welfare of disabled children.  Links/Further Information Source: {Press Notice 9 July 2009|https://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20090810173359/http://www.dcsf.gov.uk/pns/DisplayPN.cgi?pn_id=2009_0131} accessed 2021-03-01Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-05-30

An independent, not-for-profit membership organisation dedicated to raising levels of achievement in secondary education.Source: {SSATrust|http://www.ssatuk.co.uk/about/what-we-do/} accessed 2015-06-11 Further information below from The Knowledge accessed 2019-05-30 New role in developing special schools as leaders Ed Balls announced on 28 September 2009 that the SSAT would be taking forward a 550,000 project to develop special schools as leaders in teaching and learning practice for children with the most complex learning difficulties, meeting a commitment in the 21st century schools system White Paper.  The White Paper: Your child, your schools, our future: building a 21st century schools system committed the Department to commission work on developing special schools as leaders in teaching and learning practice for children with the most complex needs which SSAT won following an open competition. History SSAT began life in 1992 as the Technology Colleges Trust when it launched a school affiliation scheme. It changed its name to the Specialist Schools Trust in 2003. It then became the Specialist Schools and Academies Trust on 29 September 2005 to reflect the Trusts new support role for the academies programme.

The Secondary Schools Examinations Council (SSEC) was set up by the Board of Education on 12 September 1917 (Circular 1010) to assist in the introduction of a new scheme for the better organisation of examinations in secondary schools. These were School Certificate and Higher School Certificate. It was chaired by Rev William Temple with representatives of the examining bodies, the Teachers Registration Council, and local authority organisations. The Council produced a number of small reports on examinations and the Norwood report on curriculum and examinations. In 1964 its functions were transferred to the Schools Council. Source Board of Education. Report for the year 1916-17.  This page was produced by the Library.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-05-31

The School Standards and Framework Act 1998 was introduced by the Department for Education and Employment and received royal assent on 20 July 1998. The School Support Staff Negotiating Body (SSSNB) was first formally announced in September 2007 and began operating from October 2008. An independent chair, Philip Ashmore, was appointed to head up the Body. SSSNB was an Advisory NDPB sponsored by the Department for Education. Definition: School Teachers Pay and Conditions Document
Meaning: This document sets out the pay and conditions for school teachers in England, including pay ranges, allowances, safeguarding, working time and professional responsibilities. The STRB is an advisory body that reviews teachers' pay and working conditions in England. Its recommendations cover the duties and working time of school teachers, as well as their remuneration.  Each year the STRB is issued a remit by the SoS, and publish a report into their findings. The government gnerally accepts any recommendations from this report, unless their is a clear and compelling reason not to.

Definition: Trends in Mathematics and Science Study
Meaning: The Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study (TIMSS) is a collaborative project between the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA), national governments and the TIMSS & PIRLS International Study Centre at Boston College. TIMMS collects data at international grades four and eight (Years 5 and 9 respectively in England). Within each country: 170 schools (including independent) from each grade(year) are randomly selected to participate Within each participating school 30 pupils are selected at random A separate questionnaire is also completed by the teacher and school (there is also a parent questionnaire but this is not administered in England) The study is conducted on a four-year cycle - TIMSS Cycles: 1995 - 41 Countries 1999 - 38 Countries 2003 - 46 Countries 2007 - 62 Countries 2011 - 67 Countries 2015 - 53 Countries The Department for Education sponsor TIMSS (and PIRLS) in England and represents the UK on the IEA's governing body. Northern Ireland and Scotland participate in the studies separately and their results are reported separately to England in the international report. TIMSS consists of specially developed tests in maths and science and background questionnaires which were completed by pupils, teachers and headteachers. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16

The Teachers' International Professional Development (TIPD) programme was introduced in May 2000. The programme provides opportunities for teachers in England to develop their teaching skills, by experiencing alternative practice in a number of key themes through short-term international study visits. Such visits also aim to create valuable international links between schools, facilitating international school partnerships and information sharing on a global level. The Programme provides 2580 places per year. Itis delivered by four providers: the British Council (BC), the League for the Exchange of Commonwealth Teachers (LECT), the HTI (HTI) and the Specialist Schools and Academies Trust (SSAT). Each Local Authority (LA) in England has its own allocation of places. Since the programme was launched, TIPD participants have visited countries across the world including Singapore, Australia, Hungary, China, Sweden and the USA to study themes such as ICT, special educational needs (SEN), citizenship and literacy. The Programme enables teachers to learn from, and contribute to, educational ideas and best practice in schools throughout the world, helping to support teachers in raising standards of teaching and learning both in England and abroad. The programme has a number of different strands with a range of opportunities available to teachers and LAs. It provides the opportunity to share good practice develop international educational links with other schools carry out research share information with a network of other participants reflect on own practiceSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-17

The Teaching and Leadership Innovation Fund is a 3-year investment worth 75 million, which will support high-quality professional development for teachers and school leaders in the areas and schools in England that need it most. The aims of the fund are to: improve the provision of teachers continuing professional development (CPD) and leadership development in areas and schools that are facing challenges stimulate the demand for provision of teachers CPD and leadership development in areas and schools that are facing challenges support the development of a sustainable market in CPD and leadership development that will be capable of becoming self-funding in the future The overall aim is to improve the outcomes of children and young people, thereby making a significant contribution towards tackling social mobility.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/guidance/teaching-and-leadership-innovation-fund} accessed 2017-10-11

The Teenage Pregnancy Independent Advisory Group (TPIAG) was set up in 2000 to advise the Government on the Teenage Pregnancy Strategy and to monitor its implementation. The Government announced on October 14th, 2010 that it would be closed down. The strategy aims to Halve the rate of conceptions to under-18s by 2010. Increase the participation of teenage parents in education, training and employment. TPIAG currently has 12 members, each with specific expertise in key areas. Members are appointed by the Minister for Children, Young People and Families, for fixed terms, following open competition, in accordance with the Nolan rules for NDPBs. The group meets on a quarterly basis, with additional sub-group meetings as needed. The chair and members have an ongoing dialogue with the relevant government departments, and regularly participate in meetings around the country, make presentations, visit projects and work with the media. TPIAG publishes annual reports, to which the Government makes a formal response. The last report was published in November 2009. The group also publishes occasional reports on specific topics and responds to Government consultations.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16

01 April 2018 - The Teaching Regulation Agency (TRA) is an executive agency of the Department for Education (DfE). The purpose of the agency is to take action on receipt of allegations of serious teacher misconduct and to support employers, schools and headteachers with safeguarding responsibilities. It provides employers with access to the database of qualified teachers (DQT) in order for them to complete pre-recruitment checks to ensure that they are employing teachers who are not prohibited from teaching and who are appropriately qualified for their role. In addition, the agency acts on behalf of the Secretary of State as the Competent Authority for teaching in England. This role includes the recognition of the professional status of appropriately-qualified teachers from outside England and the award of qualified teacher status (QTS).Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/teaching-regulation-agency/about} accessed 2018-04-16

The Research Informed Practice Site (TRIPS) is a part of the DfE website that offers easy access to essential research findings for teachers, governors, parents and all those who support them in the education of school age students. Grouped under themes such as Assessment and Gender, the TRIPS site provides accessible digests of research which: use plain language and clear illustrations; allow readers to move simply between different ideas and digests according to their interests; and look at some of the implications for practitioners that arise from the practical questions posed in the digests. Much of this evidence can found in research journals and other sources that take time, energy and often money to access. The site takes articles from research journals and summarises them with the needs of practitioners in mind.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16

The Training Standards Council (TSC) was the regulator for employment training standards and practice. It was a private limited company, based in Oxford, incorporated on 29 August 1997 and dissolved on 5 April 2004. The government's plans to reform post-16 education and training outside universities in England, outlined in the White Paper Learning to Succeed, demonstrated its commitment to work-based training and led to the provision of post-16 learning being merged under a new national body, the Learning and Skills Council. The LSC would be an independent inspectorate to assess the quality of provision for adult learning and work-based training and would build on the work undertaken by the Training Standards Council. Source Companies House BBC News Archive ViaSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-17

Over one thousand schools are set to receive expert support from some of the countrys highest performing schools as the Department for Education announces six new Teaching School Hubs today (7 January [2020]). Schools will benefit from a three-year programme of support, with each of the six successful schools acting as a regional hub and will receive funding to support between 200 to 300 other schools in the local area. This will give struggling schools direct access to the expertise from school leaders with a track record of improving challenging schools. Support could include delivering tailored professional development for teachers, hosting observations and visits or deploying system leaders to offer advice and guidance to local schools. This forms part of a new scheme, launched by the department last year, to simplify and strengthen how the government drives up school standards, building on the successes of the Teaching Schools and National Leaders of Education programmes.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentews/struggling-schools-set-for-specialist-support} accessed 2020-04-07
Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-17

Transatlantic School Innovation Alliance (TSIA) is a partnership designed to improve teaching and learning, and urban leadership through the creation of a network of schools in the UK and US. The goal is to blend the ideas and strategies from educators in the two countries with relevant research, and to design study and disseminate better ways of working. TSIA was piloted in 2006-07 and started fully in 2007-08 in and involves eight (rising to 12) schools from London. The partnership extended to the Black Country in the 2009-10 academic year and involves five schools with eight schools by summer 2010. Greater Manchester Challenge schools will join in January 2010 with 10 schools. The partnership closely mirrors many of the aims of City Challenge to raise standards and aspirations in these urban schools. There has been positive feedback from London schools that it is helping raise literacy levels by identifying, adapting and implementing successful ideas. The aims of the TSIA are: to focus on innovation; schools to drive their own development; to maximise the freedoms on schools and minimise bureaucracy; To identify and disseminate knowledge and skills. Links/Further Information Press Notice 19 November 2009: Black Country Challenge Children make transatlantic connection from American EmbassySource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16

An initiative set up in 1983 aimed at supporting school and college provision of technical and pre-vocational courses for 14-18 year olds. Funded by the Department of Employment. Funding withdrawn from 1991 onwards leading to the end of the scheme.Source: Oxford Dictionary of Education 2008 Further information below from The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16 The Technical and Vocational Education Initiative (TVEI) which began as a national programme in 1987 and continued until 1997-98 helped equip young people with the knowledge and skills to succeed in adult and working life. It sought to relate the whole curriculum to the world of work, to promote work experience, to involve employers in school life and to help teachers gain and understanding of industry and commerce. It was managed by Government Offices (GOs) through contracts with Training and Enterprise Councils (TECs), Local Education Authority/local education authorities (LEAs) and others. TVEI funds (over 900m in total) supported targeted projects aimed at raising young people's levels of attainment. TVEI was extensively evaluated. The evidence showed that young people's career planning skills had been improved, that the programme had encouraged them to continue their learning post-16, and that personal, interpersonal and initiative skills had been enhanced.

Transforming Youth Work Development Fund (TYWDF) was launched in 2002 with the intention of providing Local Authority youth services with additional funding to enhance the quality and capacity of youth work. This Fund has since become the Transforming Youth Work Performance Improvement Fund (TYWPIF). Aims of the fund 10 million was pledged by Ministers for each of 2003-04, 2004-05 and 2005-06 for the youth work programme. The key aims of the TYWDF were to: Support the implementation of Youth Service Plans Build capacity within the voluntary sector Introduce innovative and imaginative projects - particularly around cultural diversity, the promotion of Community Cohesion and the reduction of youth crime and anti-social behaviour Continue to bring youth services into closer engagement with Connexions The TYWPIF carries forward the previous agenda but also asks for youth services to focus resources on work around achieving performance measures.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16

Definition: Transforming Youth Work Performance Improvement Fund
Meaning: The Transforming Youth Work Performance Improvement Fund (TYWPIF) is the successor to the Transforming Youth Work Development Fund (TYWDF). It was managed by Government Offices on behalf of the Department. The TYWPIF carries forward the TYWDF agenda but also asks for youth services to focus resources on work around achieving performance measures. Priorities for the fund are: To support youth services in the planning and managing of performance indicators Help in the implementation of the Youth Service Quality Mark *Help youth services with workforce development issues Bring about regional development and inter-authority collaboration Support innovative youth work, particularly sustainable development Support youth services make provision for activities in accordance with the Special Education Needs Disability ActSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16

The Activities for Young People Programme for 16-year-olds, also known as the u-project, was aimed at young people in England who were coming to the end of compulsory education (at the end of school year 11), with no real idea of what they wanted to do next. Those young people were more likely than others of drifting out of learning and into long-term disaffection. The aim of the u-project was to aid the transition from secondary school to adult life, by providing a structured programme of challenging activity and high-quality advice and guidance to encourage participants to remain in education or to take up training or employment. Activities on the programme were designed to offer the young people personal challenges, an opportunity to reflect, and a sense of achievement.Funding from the Big Lottery Fund ended in December 2004.

Ufi was created in 1998 as the University for Industry and is a Department for Business, Innovation and Skills-supported organisation, although it is not an NDPB. Ufi is the organisation responsible for the operation of Learndirect across England, Wales and Northern Ireland, and UK online centres in England.  Remit  Ufis remit is: to be a technologically innovative and entrepreneurial force in the improvement of skills for work to focus on the lower skilled and smaller businesses in a way which complements the rest of the education and skills sector to provide other public services including advice and access to online public services through UK online centres  However, Ufi contributes beyond the worlds of adult learning and workforce development, working across government departments on government e-services, digital inclusion, prison reform, financial literacy, citizenship and community regeneration.  Learndirect  Ufi launched Learndirect in October 2000. Since its launch, nearly 2 million learners have taken Learndirect courses in subjects ranging from the Skills for Life of literacy and numeracy to languages, management, English for Speakers of Other Languages and IT at all levels. Supported by staff in centres, or at home or work by online tutors, Learndirect learners can choose to work towards nationally recognised qualifications including the Certificates in Adult Literacy and Numeracy, CLAIT and the ECDL (European Computer Driving Licence).  Additionally, the Learndirect advice service has provided free, impartial careers guidance and advice on over a million learning opportunities to more than seven million callers, and more than 17 million information and advice sessions through its website.  UK online centres  In 2003, Ufi took on responsibility for UK online centres from the Department for Education and Skills. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-02-05

The University Grants Committee was an advisory committee of the British government, which advised on the distribution of grant funding amongst the British universities. It was in existence from 1919 until 1989. Its functions have now largely been taken over by the higher education funding councils.Source: {Wikipedia|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_Grants_Committee_(United_Kingdom)} accessed 2019-06-17

The Children and Families Act 2014 places a legal duty on all state-funded schools in England, including academies and free schools to offer a free school lunch to all pupils in reception, year 1 and year 2 from September 2014.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/universal-infant-free-school-meals-guide-for-schools-and-local-authorities} accessed 2015-06-11

UK NARIC was the UK's National Agency responsible for providing information and opinion on academic, vocational and professional qualifications from across the world. As the National Agency, managed on behalf of the UK Government, UK NARIC provide the only official source of information on international education and training systems and qualifications and skills attained outside the UK. UK ENIC is the UK National Information Centre for the recognition and evaluation of international qualifications and skills. Following the UK's departure from the European Union, the UK NARIC recognition agency function has to change from a NARIC (which is an EU-only title) to an ENIC (the wider European title for national recognition agencies) in order to meet the UK's continuing treaty obligations under the Lisbon Recognition Convention. Therefore, on 1 March 2021, the UK NARIC agency title becomes UK ENIC, operated and managed by Ecctis Limited. Source accessed 2021-04-19
Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-18

Definition: UK Council for Child Internet Safety
Meaning: The UK Council for Internet Safety (UKCIS) is the successor to the UK Council for Child Internet Safety (UKCCIS), with an expanded scope to improve online safety for everyone in the UK. The Executive Board brings together expertise from a range of organisations in the tech industry, civil society and public sector.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentews/board-announced-for-new-uk-council-for-internet-safety} accessed 2019-02-18 The proposal to expand the remit of the UK Council for Child Internet Safety was outlined in the Government's Internet Safety Strategy Green Paper in October 2017. The new Council will have specific objectives reflecting children and young peoples special needs for care and protection, and will build on the pioneering work of UKCCIS in this area. The Executive Board will contain representatives of childrens organisations.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentewsew-council-for-internet-safety-in-the-uk} accessed 2019-02-18 UKCCIS is a group of more than 200 organisations drawn from across government, industry, law, academia and charity sectors that work in partnership to help keep children safe online. The Council was established in 2010 following a review by Professor Tanya Byron and discusses and takes action on topical issues concerning childrens use of the internet. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/government/groups/uk-council-for-child-internet-safety-ukccis} accessed 2015-06-11 The UK Council for Child Internet Safety (UKCCIS) was formed in September 2008. The establishment of a UK Council for Child Internet Safety was a key recommendation in Professor Tanya Byrons Report. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-18

UK Commission for Employment and Skills
Meaning: UKCES are a publicly funded, industry-led organisation that offers guidance on skills and employment issues in the UK. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/uk-commission-for-employment-and-skills/about} accessed 2015-05-28 UKCES came into operation on 1 April 2008. The UK Council for Internet Safety (UKCIS) is the successor to the UK Council for Child Internet Safety (UKCCIS), with an expanded scope to improve online safety for everyone in the UK. The Executive Board brings together expertise from a range of organisations in the tech industry, civil society and public sector.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentews/board-announced-for-new-uk-council-for-internet-safety} accessed 2019-02-18 The proposal to expand the remit of the UK Council for Child Internet Safety was outlined in the Government's Internet Safety Strategy Green Paper in October 2017. The new Council will have specific objectives reflecting children and young peoples special needs for care and protection, and will build on the pioneering work of UKCCIS in this area. The Executive Board will contain representatives of childrens organisations.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentewsew-council-for-internet-safety-in-the-uk} accessed 2019-02-18

UK Export Finance is the UK's credit agency that works to offer financial support to UK of goods and services, by way of offering guarantees, insurance and re-insurance. Its aim is to ensure that no viable UK export fails due to lack of finances or insurance, this is done sustainably and at no net cost to the taxpayer. It works to complement the private sector rather than compete with it, offering support where private sector financial institutions are unable to.

University technical colleges (UTCs) are all-ability and mixed gender state funded schools, independent of local authorities. They are not extensions of or conversions from existing provision, but new 14 to 19 academies, typically with 500-800 pupils. UTCs specialise in subjects that need modern, technical, industry-standard equipment, such as engineering and construction, and teach these disciplines alongside business skills and a broad, general education.Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/university-technical-colleges-from-2014-how-to-apply} accessed 2015-06-11

The Vetting and Barring Scheme (VBS) went live on 12 October 2009. The scheme is delivered by the Criminal Records Bureau (CRB) and the Independent Safeguarding Authority (ISA) under the Safeguarding and Vulnerable Groups Act 2006. VBS covers England, Wales and Northern Ireland; a separate but aligned scheme was implemented in Scotland in 2010.

The Vocational Certificate of Education (VCE) was introduced in September 2000 to replace the advanced General National Vocational Qualification. Following a review, VCEs were renamed GCEs (General Certificates of Education) in applied subjects or A Levels in applied subjects. The revised qualifications, which were introduced in September 2005, provide a broad introduction to vocational areas and encourage teaching and assessment approaches in work-related contexts.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04

The Voluntary and Community Sector (VCS) is an umbrella term that covers a very diverse range of providers who are working with a specific voluntary or community aim. The sector is large and varied. It is made up of charities and voluntary groups as well as informal community-based organisations. Members of the sector can vary from international, well-known companies with thousands of paid staff, to small community groups with no paid staff.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04
Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04

Virtual Education Action Zones (VEAZ) were introduced by the Department for Education and Employment in 1999. They were an innovative build-on to Education Action Zones and were designed to explore the improvements that could be achieved using information technology - with the schools set to be connected by video-conferencing and e-mail. Each of the participating schools had video-conferencing equipment installed, with access to e-mail improved for pupils and the 1,000 teachers and support staff. The schools, including both primary and secondary, were set up links in groups of three - with the groups constantly changing until all the schools have worked with each other. Source: {BBC|http:/ews.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/506381.stm} accessed 2019-03-04 and The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04

Definition: Vetinary Quality Assurance (VET QA, the S is part of assurance)
Meaning: A commercial service that APHA (part of Defra) offer to labs worldwide that test the quality of labs that test animal samples. It's a test of a test in plain English. We call these tests Proficiency Tests and VETQAS are an ISO accredited leader in this field.

Good value for money is the optimal use of resources to achieve the intended outcomes. ‘Optimal’ means ‘the most desirable possible given expressed or implied restrictions or constraints’. Value for money is not about achieving the lowest initial price.
Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04

ViSOR is a secure national database that can be accessed by the Police, Probation, and Prison services, allowing the three services to work on the same system to help reduce reoffending. This is being replaced by MAPPS (see above)

A Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) is an ICT-based environment that supports the delivery of online learning. VLEs allow controlled access to pieces of information, which can be individually assessed and recorded. VLEs also allow the tracking of student activity and progress, support of online learning, and electronic communication between the learner, tutor and others. The teacher and student have two different access levels: the teacher can see what the student sees, but has additional user rights that allow them to create or change content and to monitor each student's performance.Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04

A 'write round' is where one department writes a letter to other departments (and No10) via a cabinet committee to get collective agreement on a new policy proposal. The central process is coordinated by the Cabinet Office and it's done via private offices.

The Workforce Race Advisory Group (WRAG) grew out of the Commission for Black Staff in Further Education as an advisory body for the Department for Education and Skills (DfES); it is now part of Department for Business, Innovation and Skills. It was set up to ensure the leaders of national partner organisations and learning providers had a mechanism to advise the DfES on the issues of race equality as they impact on the sector's workforce. WRAG collectively ensures that the Commission for Black Staff in Further Education continues to shape and inform workforce development across the system by: -challenging racism -breaking down barriers for black staff and -raising the achievement level of all who work and learn in the FE system.  Membership -Association of Colleges -Association of Learning Providers -Black Leadership Initiative -Centre for Excellence in Leadership -Department for Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) (Chair of group) -Learning and Skills Council -Lifelong Learning UK (Secretariat for group) -National Institute of Adult Continuing Education -Network for Black Professionals -Office for Standards in Education -Quality Improvement Agency -University and College Union -UNISON Workplan The WRAG workplan identifies the key activities, which will support increasing the racial diversity of the workforce. It will directly contribute to the FE Workforce Strategy, the Sector Skills Agreement and Sector Qualifications Strategy. Source Lifelong Learning UK websiteSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04

The Young Apprenticeship Ambassador Network (YAAN) is a group of past and current apprentices that are members of a local YAAN in their region. The core purpose of the YAAN is to grow and expand the apprenticeship programme by engaging with and providing information on apprenticeships to young people through a number of different activities and events, including schools/6th forms and young people in school academic years 11-13. The role of the ambassador is to promote apprenticeships and inspire other young people by describing their direct experience.Source: {Amazing Apprenticeships website|https://yaan.amazingapprenticeships.com/what-is-the-yaan/} accessed 2018-01-18

A series of longitudinal surveys that contacts a sample of an academic year-group or "cohort" of young people in the spring following completion of education and usually annually until they are aged 19 or 20. The survey looks at young people's education and labour market experience, their training and qualifications and a wide range of other issues, including socio-demographic variables.Source: DfE RS Gateway as at 2011-01-17

The Young Fathers Initiative is a registered charity supported by the Department for Education that aims to: -remove barriers that currently stop young father's involvement in family life; -ensure that young fathers are informed and have the skills required to father their children well; -support children's development, by supporting the active involvement of young fathers; -provide professionals with information, advice and support to develop their work with young fathers.  The Institute plans to concentrate on the following areas: -The introduction of a school based programme preparation for fatherhood" targeted at year 10 young men as part of their PHSE and citizenship programme.-Targeted support for young fathers in employment / training (but no guarantee of a job).

The Youth Justice Board for England and Wales (YJB) is an executive NDPB. Board members are appointed by the Secretary of State for Justice. The YJB oversees the youth justice system in England and Wales. Source: {Ministry of Justice website|http://www.justice.gov.uk/about/yjb/} accessed 2015-06-11

Launched April 2010. Sponsored by the Department for Education to support the delivery of training and education to all 16-19 year olds in England. From April 1st 2012 the responsibilities of the YPLA have transferred to the Education Funding Agency.

YPMAD covers the attainment of 16-19 year olds (including some information on older ages) in England and also captures information on pupil characteristics. It is a longitudinal dataset which allows students' progress to be tracked. YPMAD is generated by matching several data sources (school census, awarding organisation and individualised learner record data). YPMAD is used to underpin the National Statistics output Level 2 and 3 attainment by young people aged 19, which is used to estimate the skill levels of the overall population at age 19. Unlike the figures in school performance tables, it is not used for accountability purposes so YPMAD allows for a longer and more consistent time-series.Source: Team source 2020-02-24

The Youth Rehabilitation Order (YRO) came into effect on 30 November 2009 and will provide judges and magistrates with a choice of 18 rigorous options from which they will be able to create a sentence specifically designed to deal with the individual circumstances of the young offender before them and so help them turn their backs on crime. The YRO will consolidate and enhance existing community sentences to enable courts to sentence in a flexible and tailored way. The YRO provides a range of sentencing options that will punish effectively and rehabilitate young people, including intensive fostering, intensive surveillance and supervision requirements, electronic monitoring, curfews, the required attendance of substance abuse or mental health programmes as well as undertaking tough community work and reparation. This could include apologising to their victim, in order to make visible amends for their crimes.

The Youth Sector Development Fund (YSDF) has been set up to provide a direct response to the commitments in Aiming High for Young People/Aiming High for young people: a ten year strategy for positive activities to build the capacity of third sector organisations. The YSDF will support third sector organisations (TSOs) that can demonstrate effective approaches to engaging and empowering young people, particularly the most disadvantaged. From April 2008, up to 100 million will be available to provide a mixture of large and small grants and expert business support to help these organisations sustain and grow their provision so that more young people can benefit from the activities they offer. Grants totalling 27m have already been awarded through the YSDF to five organisations, Leap Confronting Conflict, Fairbridge, Kids Company, Speaking up and UK Youth who each help and support some of our most disadvantaged young people.

1983/1986. One year scheme. It was introduced in September 1983, and the training period was extended to 2 years in April 1986. The scheme was replaced by Youth Training (YT) in April 1990. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-02-05

Pilot scheme ran 2003-05. Through the Young Volunteer Challenge pilot (YVC) a young person will have the opportunity to do some volunteering work after they leave school. The pilot is being run in 9 areas within England until September 2005, and offers opportunities for 820 young people for whom finance is the main barrier to participate in volunteering. This full-time initiative (full-time is defined as more than 30 hours per week) will target 18 and 19 year olds who have completed their programmes of post-16 learning with the support of an Education Maintenance Allowance (EMA), or were eligible for Income Support while undertaking vocational training. The age range will be extended to 21 years for young people with special needs or disabilities. Volunteers will receive a weekly allowance of 45, and an end of experience award of 750 after completing 9 months experience. The pilot will also seek to enhance the personal development of the volunteers in such areas as communication, personal planning, teamwork and leadership skills as well as their commitment to further learning, employment and volunteering. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-02-05
